July 20, 2014: Fiction
INVISIBLE, by James Patterson and David Ellis. (Little, Brown.) A former F.B.I.
researcher finds a link between scores of apparently unconnected unsolved cases.
THE SILKWORM, by Robert Galbraith. (Mulholland/Little, Brown.) The private
detective Cormoran Strike in literary London; by J. K. Rowling, writing
pseudonymously.
TOP SECRET TWENTY-ONE, by Janet Evanovich. (Bantam.) The New Jersey
bounty hunter Stephanie Plum pursues a dealer who sells more than used cars.
MR. MERCEDES, by Stephen King. (Scribner.) A driver plows into a crowd, killing
eight. The killer then taunts a suicidal ex-cop, who must stop another, deadlier
attack.
THE CITY, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam.) A musician, part of a famous family, looks
back over the events of his life, beginning during his childhood in the 1960s.
THE GOLDFINCH, by Donna Tartt. (Little, Brown.)  A painting smuggled out of the
Metropolitan Museum of Art after a bombing becomes a boy’s prize, guilt and
burden.
WRITTEN IN MY OWN HEART'S BLOOD, by Diana Gabaldon. (Delacorte.) Jamie
Fraser and his family face challenges in the 18th and 20th centuries.
ALL FALL DOWN, by Jennifer Weiner. (Atria.) A woman becomes addicted to pain
medication.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World War
II.
THE VACATIONERS, by Emma Straub. (Riverhead.) An Upper West Side couple,
their children and their friends confront life’s changes during two weeks in Mallorca.
ONE PLUS ONE, by Jojo Moyes. (Pamela Dorman/Viking.) An obnoxious tech
millionaire comes to the rescue of a single mom and her kids heading for a math
contest that could change their lives.
WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE'S THE JEDI DOTH RETURN, by Ian Doescher. (Quirk
Books.) Jabba the Hutt, Ewoks and the redemption of Anakin Skywalker, all in
iambic pentameter.
THE HURRICANE SISTERS, by Dorothea Benton Frank. (Morrow/HarperCollins.)
Three generations of women endure a stormy summer in South Carolina's
Lowcountry.
THE MATCHMAKER, by Elin Hilderbrand. (Little, Brown.) A Nantucket resident’s life
Non-Fiction
BLOOD FEUD, by Edward Klein. (Regnery.) A journalist describes animosity
behind the alliance between the Clinton and Obama families.
HARD CHOICES, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Simon & Schuster.) Clinton’s
memoir focuses on her years as secretary of state and her views about the
American role in the world.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House.) An Olympic runner’s story
of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
ONE NATION, by Ben Carson with Candy Carson. (Sentinel.) Carson, a retired
pediatric neurosurgeon, now a Fox News contributor, offers solutions to problems
in health and education based on capitalism, not government.
CAPITAL IN THE TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY, by Thomas Piketty.
(Belknap/Harvard University.) A French economist’s analysis of centuries of
economic history predicts worsening inequality and proposes solutions.
THINK LIKE A FREAK, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner.
(Morrow/HarperCollins.) How to solve problems creatively, from the authors of
“Freakonomics.”
DIARY OF A MAD DIVA, by Joan Rivers. (Berkley.) Humorous reflections about
life, pop culture and celebrities.
I AM MALALA, by Malala Yousafzai with Christina Lamb. (Little, Brown.) The
experience of the Pakistani girl who advocated for women’s education and was
shot by the Taliban.
FLASH BOYS, by Michael Lewis. (Norton.) The world of high-frequency computer-
driven trading; from the author of "Liar's Poker."
DAVID AND GOLIATH, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown.) How disadvantages
can work in our favor.
LEAN IN, by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf.) The chief operating
officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.
THE ROMANOV SISTERS, by Helen Rappaport. (St. Martin's.) The story of the
daughters of the last czar, who were executed in 1918.
THE CLOSER, by Mariano Rivera with Wayne Coffey. (Little, Brown.) A memoir
by the great Yankees pitcher.
HOW NOT TO BE WRONG, by Jordan Ellenberg. (Penguin Press.) A
mathematician shows how his discipline helps us think about problems of politics,
medicine and commerce.
